p.div:
Welcome to Shopify!
In this guide, youâ€™ll learn the basics of opening, customizing and managing your new online store. Shopify provides you with a variety of tools to make your venture into your business easy and customizable.
The Pricing PlansShopify offers different pricing plans based on your individual needs as an entrepreneur. Detailed below are what each plan offers. https://www.shopify.com/pricing

conbody.p: To begin selling, you have to have an existing store. These steps will give you the basics on how to properly set up all the components of your store.

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, go to Settings.
Click General.
Locate the Store Details section and fill in all the necessary information.
Click Save.

task.title: Adding Store Policies
task.shortdesc: Policies are important so that your customers know how you handle refunds, privacy, and terms of service for transactions. Store policies are added on a different webpage, but will be displayed as links at the bottom of the customer checkout page for your store. This requires 2 separate browser tabs to be open.

step.cmd: In your Pages page, click Create a New Page
In a separate tab, access your store checkout settings. Copy each policy to your computersâ€™ clipboard.
Back to the first page, paste the clipboard contents. Then click Save Page.
Add a link to the policies page so your customers can easily find it.
From the Shopify Admin page, click on the Products tab to go to the Products page.
Click Add Product to begin the process of adding in new products.
Enter in the details and logistics for your new product.

task.title: Organizing Products
task.shortdesc: Shopify allows you to create product collections to organize your products however youâ€™d like through the use of collections. Examples of categories: Clothes for men, women, or children Items on sale Items of a certain type, size or color Seasonal products

step.cmd: From the Collections page, click on Create Collection
In the new window, enter a Title and Description for the collection. This is a mandatory step.
Under Sales Channels make sure to choose which channels you want the collection to be listed under. (I.E. Shopify online store, Facebook, Amazon, etc.)
Collections allow you to choose whether products will be added in manually or automatically. This option cannot be changed later.

substep.cmd: If you chose automatically: Add in the selection criteria under Conditions.
If you chose manually: When adding in products manually at a later time, make sure you click Save after adding them. You can add the same product to several different collections.

step.cmd: Click Save Collection

task.title: Domain Through Shopify
task.shortdesc: Shopify has the ability to host your online store through either a third-party domain or one thatâ€™s been bought from us.

step.cmd: Navigate to the domain purchasing page, on shopify.
To see if the domain name you want is available click Domain Search and type the domain in the text box. Click Generate domains to search.
If the domain name is available, or an alternative is, choose which one you want, but be sure to look at the yearly price as well, since different domains have different prices.
Follow the prompts from there and if fully seen through, youâ€™ll have a new domain for your Shopify shop!
From the Shopify Admin page, click Verify connection to verify that your domain has been connected to your store.

task.title: Set your primary domain
task.shortdesc: The primary domain of your storefront is the domain name that customers see in the browserâ€™s address bar.

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, go to the Online Store > Domains.
In Primary Domain, click Change primary domain.
Select the domain you would like set as the primary from the prompt.
Click Save.
From the Shopify Admin page, go to Online Store > Domains.
In Third-party domains, locate the domain you want to remove and click Remove.
Click Remove again to confirm.

conbody.p: New customers will have their names and information added to customer lists when they place an order in your store, allowing you to email them using their profile information. You are also able to add, edit, or delete customer profiles manually in certain circumstances. Using this information, you can create a customer group for sending emails or discounts to customers.

step.cmd: Go to the Customers page from the Shopify Admin, and click the Add customer button.
Input the information on the form, updating the checkboxes as necessary

substep.cmd: Customer accepts marketing means that the customer has agreed to receive newsletters or marketing emails.

Collect tax details if you are charging a sales tax for the customer. Depending on the customerâ€™s, or your own location, there will be additional options or information, such as tax exemption options with Browse or search exemptions.

step.cmd: After filling out all the appropriate information, click Save customer to create or update the customer profile.
On the Shopify Admin, click the Customers button, and select the profiles of the customers you want to email.
Click the customerâ€™s email address in the Customer overview, and then edit the subject as necessary ( {{ shop.name }} can be used to automatically generate your storeâ€™s name in an email).
Type your message in the message field, and if you want to keep a copy for records, enter the email you want the copies sent to in the Send bcc to field.
Click the Review email when you are done, and then click Send notification if you are satisfied with the message, or Back if you want to revise the message.

conbody.p: Go to the Customers page from the Shopify Admin, and click the Edit customer button.

step.cmd: From your Shopify admin, go to Customers.
Click the name of the customer profile that you want to edit.
In the Default Address section, click Manage to view or edit existing addresses.
In the Manage Addresses dialog, click Edit address under the address that you want to edit.
Change the customer's address details and click Save.

context.p: Using tags can help you organize your customer profile list. You can use tags to label your customers with categories or descriptive terms. For example, if you have wholesale customers, then you can tag those customers as wholesale.

step.cmd: From your Shopify admin, go to Customers
Click the name of the customer profile you want to edit.
In the Tags section, add or edit your customer profile tags in the text box.
Click Save to confirm your changes.

task.title: Edit a Customer's Name or Email

step.cmd: From your Shopify admin, go to the Customers sections.
Click the name of the customer profile you want to edit.
In the Customer overview section, click Edit.
step.info:
In the Edit customer dialog, you can change the customers:
First name.
Last name.
Email address.
Phone Number
Acklodgement to receive marketing

step.cmd: Click Save to confirm your changes to the customer profileâ€™s Information.

conbody.p:
New orders will appear in the orders page when a customer makes a purchase from one of your online stores or sales channels. Orders are categorized into 3 different states in the processing flow:
Order has been placed (Capturing payments): This occurs when customers use a credit/debit card to purchase and order. During this time, the bank is processing the purchase and determining whether the funds can be spent or not.
Order has been paid (Fulfilling order): At this point, itâ€™s up to you to ship their order, hence why this process is referred to as order fulfillment.
Order has been fulfilled and paid (Archive the order): The order has been both paid for and shipped. The customer has received their order, so thereâ€™s no need to process the order further.

The overview shows you the overall status of all the orders placed by customers. Customers are given the option to receive links to their order status page by email. The email sent to them is a template that includes the page URL the order status page that tells them:

task.title: Customizing your Email Templates
task.shortdesc: The email templates control the Order confirmation and Shipping emails that customers are sent when their orders are fulfilled or updated. These emails are automatically sent to customers, but can be customized to fit what you would like the customers to see.

context.p: Customization is formatted using HTML, so if you need help understanding how it works, check out this simple guide.

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin Page, go to Settings > Notifications.
Locate the Email Templates section, then find the Order confirmation and Shipping confirmation email templates.

conbody.p: Shopify allows several different types of payment methods through storefronts. Payment methods are further customizable by storefront owners, as they can choose which type of payments to accept and decline, as well as methods based on if transactions take place in real life, or over the online storefront.These options include:

li.p: Credit/Debit cards
Cash (For in-person transactions)
Manual card payments (customer enters in card details manually)
Gift Cards
On the Orders screen, tap the search icon.
In the search field, enter in either the order ID, receipt number, or customer name. Results will appear beneath the search bar.

context.p: Choose an order to open it up, or tap Cancel to return to the previous screen.

li.p: From the Shopify POS, tap Orders.
Choose the order of the item that needs to be refunded.
Tap Refund or Exchange and then tap which item(s) which will be refunded, then use the + or - buttons to enter the quantity of the item that will be refunded.
There are several optional choices that can be added based on the nature of the refund and the seller.

context.p: Once all constraints are satisfied, tap Refund then Done.

conbody.p: In the Overview dashboard you can do the following activities:

li.p: check the value of your recent sales and compare them to a previous time period
compare how well your sales channels are performing
track your average order value
see where your visitors are coming fromâ€”by region or by social media source
monitor the trends over time

conbody.p: The dashboard shows the most valuable metrics that give you insight into the performance of your store and the behavior of your customers. The metrics are shown in numeric format and also as graphs where appropriate. For all the metrics, the percentage change from the previous date range can also be shown.

li.p: 1.) From your Shopify admin, go to Analytics > Dashboards. By default, the dashboard shows data for today compared to yesterday.

2.) If you want to see data for another date range, then click the date menu and select a different date range. You can select a preset range, such as Last 30 days, or you can set any custom range by clicking dates on the calendar.
3.) If you want to show comparisons with the previous period or to the same date range from the previous year, then check Compare to previous dates and select a comparison value.
4.) Click Apply.

context.p: 5.) Optional: If the View report link is shown, then click it to see more details about the metric. Not all metrics have a report, and you need to be on a plan that provides the detailed Shopify

section.title: What is Shopifyâ€™s IP address?
section.p: When using a third-party or external domain for your shop, usually you must state shopifyâ€™s IP address for the third-party provider. If so, it is 23.227.38.65. This IP will need to be set as your A record on the other site.

title.b: How do I change my myshopify.com domain?

section.p: You cannot because your myshopify.com domain is a URL that is a unique identifier for your store, therefore it canâ€™t be changed or removed. However, it can be replaced with a custom domain name.

title.b: Why isnâ€™t my Shopify POS synced with my Shopify Admin?

section.p: The Shopify POS app usually updates automatically with any changes made on the admin page, but if you find the desktop and mobile apps arenâ€™t synced with the same information, you can force the app to resync with the Shopify admin.
From the Shopify POS app, press your Ipadâ€™s home button to send the app into the background.
From the Ipadâ€™s home screen, find and tap the Shopify POS app.
Check to see if the app has been updated with the new changes.
If the app still hasnâ€™t updated, force close the app, then reopen it.
Double tap the home button to bring up all of the running apps on the Ipad.
Located the shopify app and swipe the window up until the window has left the screen.
Tap the home button again, then located the Shopify POS app and tap it open.

section.title: Website Domain
section.p: The name of the website or URL, sometimes called the host name. A web domain is an actual presence on the Internet, such as a web page. A web domain name is a substitute that replaces the Internet Protocol (IP) address. For example, we can replace the IP address 207.97.195.109 with a domain name such as www.shopify.com.

section.title: Traffic Sources
section.p: A report that provides an overview of the different kinds of sources that send people to your website.

li.p: Direct Traffic:People who show up to the site by directly using the URL associated with it or from using a bookmark.
Social: Other websites that send traffic over to you. These are commonly through social media sites such as Twitter and Facebook where the URL for the storefront is shared.
Email: Traffic from emails that included links to the URL.

ul.li: Unknown: Traffic from places that cannot be determined. This is a common category.
